benchmark_details.name: WACK Benchmarks
benchmark_details.overview: WACK is a framework for assessing white-box hallucination mitigation techniques in open-book and closed-book contexts for large language models (LLMs). It categorizes examples based on the modelâ€™s prior knowledge and creates datasets for effective intervention strategies.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To improve the reliability of large language models (LLMs) by mitigating hallucinations through effective intervention strategies.
audience: Researchers in AI and Natural Language Processing
out_of_scope_uses: Any use of the data for malicious purposes such as increasing hallucinations

data.source: Automated dataset generation based on model knowledge types from selected examples in DisentQA and TriviaQA datasets.
data.size: Approximately 4,000 examples for each of the datasets created.
data.annotation: Labeled for hallucination (errors) and grounded (correct) outputs.

methods: Dataset construction through automated classification of model knowledge
Intervention via modification of model activations
methodology.calculation: Metrics are calculated by comparing model outputs against labeled datasets for hallucination and grounded responses.
methodology.interpretation: Higher accuracy indicates better performance for mitigating hallucinations without compromising the model's overall capabilities.
methodology.validation: Experimental validation through multiple model settings and evaluation on both open and closed-book settings.

targeted_risks.harm: Interventions and evaluations must be conducted carefully to avoid exacerbating hallucinations.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.data_licensing: The datasets were created for research purposes and are publicly available without explicit licensing restrictions.
ethical_and_legal_considerations.compliance_with_regulations: The benchmarks were designed to comply with general ethical standards in AI research.
